Allan Sandage, the Journal of the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada, Vol. 83, No. 6, December 1989, "Edwin Hubble 1889-1953", p.6

"The most curious impression we are left with [about Hubble] is his lack of comment on the significance of the redshift phenomenon, which is surely one of the most important discoveries in science. In none of his writings did Hubble comment on the central importance that the form of the redshift-distance law is linear ... Discovery of the linear form is usually taken to be as important as the discovery of the expansion itself if the phenomenon has any relevance to 'the creation of the universe'."
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - Hubble Never Commented on Any Linearity in the Redshift-Distance Law
